message_1:
Let's say a student is studying relevance logic and has learned about the concept of entailment. Here's a precise numerical problem for them to solve:

Suppose the premises P: "It is raining outside" and Q: "I forgot my umbrella at home" entail the conclusion R: "I will get wet walking to work." However, we now learn that Q is irrelevant to R. That is, even if Q is false, it does not affect the truth of R. Using relevance logic, can we still say that P and Q entail R? Why or why not?
message_2:
In relevance logic, an entailment holds only if the premises are relevant to the conclusion. In this case, we are given that Q is irrelevant to R. This means that the truth of R does not depend on the truth of Q. 

Since Q is irrelevant to R, we cannot say that P and Q together entail R in the context of relevance logic. Instead, we can say that P alone entails R, as the truth of R depends on the truth of P (i.e., if it is raining outside, then the person will get wet walking to work, regardless of whether they have an umbrella or not). 

In summary, using relevance logic, we cannot say that P and Q entail R, because Q is irrelevant to R. The entailment would hold between P and R alone.
